results.title: There are yachts at the bottom of my garden
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Malcolm Otton and Jack Rogers
results.brief_description: Many people believe that eighteen footers are the most exciting boats racing on Sydney Harbour. They certainly attract more spectators than any other class of boat. This film talks about sailing on Sydney Harbour. By contrast with those who live in one of the world’s capitals, such as London, and who may have to drive some distance to reach their boats, the average Sydney sailor is lucky: there are literally yachts at the bottom of the garden.

results.title: There's nothing that doesn't take time
results.brief_description: Oshiro Sakai, an elderly Japanese woman, talks about her life as she weaves a basket. She is also shown teaching young girls how to make baskets in the traditional way. Japanese dialogue with English voiceover.

results.title: There's no place like earth
results.brief_description:
Fantastic interactive work created as part of Project Snap by digital artist Ruth Fleishman and writer Jacinta Parsons in collaboration with local programmer Mark Johnson and Grade 5/6 students of Footscray West Primary on the topic of their local environment.
Each class concentrated on a different environmental theme and combined that with their study of the earth’s atmosphere. The themes include: Earth’s crust; Waterways; Earth’s surface; Troposphere - pollution; Troposphere - global warming.

results.creator_credit: Craig Baynes productions and Craig Baynes
results.brief_description: The story of a tire, the many complex steps needed in its production, and the men and women who have contributed their efforts in its manufacture.

results.title: There's always a better way. No. 2
results.brief_description: Illustrates how modern manufacturing methods, using highly mechanized equipment, have reduced the production cost for locomotive wheels. Shows the use of a special block-breaker increasing production from 24 to 315 ingot sections per shift; the mechanical handling and cleaning of heated ingots; the operation of a 1,000 ton press, moulding and forging a half ton ingot in the short period of two minutes.

results.title: There's always a better way. No. 1
results.brief_description: Illustrates five ways in which new manufacturing techniques have reduced production costs; the removal of covering material in electrical cables using a foot operated device; binding vacuum cleaner bags to plastic caps; turning tubes of cloth inside out; provision of work benches for maximum efficiency; the use of two planing machines in series simplifying handling of timber to be planed on both sides.

results.title: There's a way
results.brief_description: A dramatized account of how, with improvisation and a relatively small expense, a modest rehabilitation department can be set up in a hospital. Patients are brought back to normal life and work more quickly through group treatment, and existing hospital resources are used to better advantage with a quicker turnover of patients.

results.title: There's a hippopotamus on our roof eating cake
results.creator_credit: Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education
results.brief_description: Hazel Edwards wrote the award winning “Hippo” book with the help of her children. Featuring Deborah Niland’s colourful and lively illustrations, the story has won world wide acclaim and has been translated into many languages including Japanese and Braille. The story centres around the lovable and lively “Hippo”, who can do anything especially the things you are not allowed to do!

results.title: Theramin
results.brief_description:
The theremin (/ˈθɛrəmɪn/; originally known as the ætherphone/etherphone, thereminophone[2] or termenvox/thereminvox) is an electronic musical instrument controlled without physical contact by the thereminist (performer). It is named after its inventor, Léon Theremin (Лев Термен), who patented the device in 1928.

The instrument’s controlling section usually consists of two metal antennas that sense the relative position of the thereminist’s hands and control oscillators for frequency with one hand, and amplitude (volume) with the other. The electric signals from the theremin are amplified and sent to a loudspeaker.

The sound of the instrument is often associated with eerie situations. Thus, the theremin has been used in movie soundtracks such as Miklós Rózsa’s Spellbound and The Lost Weekend, Bernard Herrmann’s The Day the Earth Stood Still, and Justin Hurwitz’s First Man, as well as in theme songs for television shows such as the ITV drama Midsomer Murders. The theremin is also used in concert music (especially avant-garde and 20th- and 21st-century new music), and in popular music genres such as rock.
